abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Rural Roads Project
            for Tunisia were as follows: the outcome was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons indicate
            that task teams should make an effort to use, if not the
            tool itself, the logic imposed by the project framework
            matrix. The Project focused on priority objectives that were
            clearly valued by the client. The project's simplicity
            paid off. This allowed the Bank and the Implementing Agency
            (IA) to focus on few, relevant components and reform areas
            and ensure those could be systematically pursued. The Bank
            would have benefited from more carefully listening to the
            client on the issue of paving versus graveling of roads.
            Clearly this component had no real buy from IA. The IA did
            end up carrying out this component successfully and drew
            useful lessons from it, but the pilot is unlikely to be
            scaled up and mainstreamed. The risk of inadequate
            commitment towards this technique and its mainstreaming was
            brushed aside during the preparation or at least
            insufficiently mitigated. On the issue of the length of the
            project, the Bank demonstrated to be rather inflexible and
            was proven wrong by the client which implemented the bulk of
            the project within the four years it had anticipated. The
            Bank insisted to follow predominant country's
            standards, but would have benefited from a more flexible
            approach. The objective of deconcentrating the function to
            the Regional Councils (RCs) was doomed from the start, for
            the reasons explained above. The lesson to be drawn from
            this is that complex public sector management issues, such
            as decentralization, take time and highest senior level
            commitment to be carried out and cannot be pursued through a
            project focused on physical construction and improvements,
            and within a Ministry that has really no stake in this, and
            would not draw benefits from, such reforms, possibly the
            opposite. Decentralization and empowerment of local
            authorities remain an important objective in Tunisia that
            should be pursued through public reform projects, specific
            and well targeted projects and implemented by the agencies
            that can draw benefits and have incentives in pursuing such
            reforms, with high level government commitment and with a
            long time frame and implementation period. The project did
            well to insist on the involvement of the private sector for
            rural road works. This component made a big impact and it
            has permanently changed the way works are undertaken in
            rural roads in the country. The success of this component
            should serve as example also to other transport sub-sector
            and provide a best case scenario where the reluctance of the
            IA to reduce public sector involvement initially was later
            overcome by the positive effects of the private sector involvement.

18225288.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18225288.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Other financial and private sector development,Other accountability/anti-corruption,Decentralization

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Rural Roads
            Project are public sector restructuring, budgetary reforms,
            private sector development, the development of improved road
            standards, the reduction of disparities between urban and
            rural areas, the reduction of rural to urban migration, and
            improving the delivery of social services to the poorer
            population. The objectives will be realized through
            improving maintenance of rural roads, particularly unpaved
            ones; decentralizing road management responsibilities to
            local governments, without developing new entities;
            establishing a link between budgets and road classification;
            strengthening budgetary disciplines, transparency and
            accountability; targeting specific road maintenance tasks
            for execution by contract to improve efficiency and to
            create new development opportunities for a dynamic private
            sector; and finally minimizing life-cycle costs by making
            optimum use of gravel road techniques. The project includes:
            1) the preparation and initial implementation of an
            institutional reform program; 2) the periodic rehabilitation
            of approximately 300 km of gravel roads in a pilot program
            to be carried out by contract in ten Governorates; and 3)
            the upgrading of about 715 km of priority rural roads to
            appropriate standards.
